poem:
**At the Till**

Coins clink,  
thin echoes,  
in a basket of burden.  
Prices rise  
like weary clouds,  
gray threats  
over the heads of the many.  
Shelves whisper  
of savings,  
smug and elusive.  
Still, the hands reach—  
a dance of grasp and let go—  
balancing wants  
in the weight of need.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Asda says new business taxes mean customers are ‘feeling it’ at the till New business taxes mean “the consumer is feeling it” as companies pass on their costs to shoppers, according to the boss of Asda. However, Allan Leighton said the supermarket chain was investing to keep a lid on prices and attract cash-strapped shoppers. The UK’s third largest supermarket chain, which is at risk of being overtaken by the discounter Aldi, said sales fell". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Asda says new business taxes mean customers are ‘feeling it’ at the till New business taxes mean “the consumer is feeling it” as companies pass on their costs to shoppers, according to the boss of Asda. However, Allan Leighton said the supermarket chain was investing to keep a lid on prices and attract cash-strapped shoppers. The UK’s third largest supermarket chain, which is at risk of being overtaken by the discounter Aldi, said sales fell
